I do not think we should get a season two-maybe a movie would be good- but i think itended at the perfect moment.Not shorter,not longer.Just on time.\n\n

Yeah, I'm writing my first review on a three-year-old anime that I've only seen four episodes of. Got a problem with that? Don't care.
Story - 1
I realize that I don't have all the pieces to this puzzle, but when each piece is the size of my thumb in length and width and there're only six of them, I don't really need them all to get the picture. It's very cliche, and I swear to god I wrote the same freaking story in fifth grade. This is by far the worst element of the show, and I say that with confidence even having not finished theshow.


Also, exposition. Every of the exposition. Like, there's one part in the first episode where they show that regular people cannot see these monsters by having one such beast run past a couple of girls who don't even look up from their conversation, however when it comes to anything important, like the story, everything is explained via talking head scenes.


Also, plot holes if you think about any event for more than three seconds.


Art - 6


The show looks great. The animation is fantastic, for the most part, sometimes it just feel like they're faking it, but they're faking it well, so it's okay. The character designs, while a bit on the average side and a bit forgettable, were nice while I watched it.


Mirai was the most unique looking out of every character who had more than one scene up to episode 4, and all she is is pink with glasses. I mean, she's absolutely adorable, and that seems to be her only function, but I don't even know where to look when I look at her. All I see is a pink fluff ball.


Sound - 5


The music during the lighthearted scenes just sounded so bubbly that anytime the show started to get serious, it just looked like it was trying to be as edgy as possible. As for the dramatic music, I cannot remember what it sounds like off the top of my head, but I would assume it's orchestral and dramatic n' shit. I never found myself disliking anything I heard, it just didn't seem like all of the music fit exactly right.


Character - 3


Water dose?


Really, though, after the second episode, every conflict with Mirai and main character guy, whose name I forget because I couldn't care less about this non-character, had my rolling my eyes. Then, everything any character does ever has literally no purpose.


Like, "Ima fight the big bad boss monster!" Why? "because I killed my friend because boss monster possessed her!" Yeah, okay, but why are you attacking it now? "... See answer B?"


Then, and this probably should have been said in the story section, they don't even go over how they got into such a situation as to allow the friend girl to be possessed by the boss monster. Like, everyone in this city has fair warning, so how was the other place any different?


You know what? I'm going back and dropping story by a point.


Enjoyment - 3


Eh. Didn't make me feel, and it never really got intense. It's just basic enough so as to not completely bore me, but there's not much worth coming back to.


Overall - 5


There's a cute pink fluff ball of a girl, and that is the most this show will give you. Otherwise, it's nothing. It's literally nothing. I'm not sure how else to describe it. It's just stimulation for the brain. Just something your eyes can see and your ears can hear.

Kyoukai no Kanata or "Beyond the Boundary" was a really good series. I enjoyed every episode in the series from start to finish. Here's my review of it.
Story: 8
The story was unique, but it did remind me of Bleach and Yu Yu Hakusho. Every time I hear about Spirit Work Warriors, I think of Soul Reapers or Spirit Detectives. And the Youmu reminded me of Hollows in the Bleach series. It was packed with action and awesome looking fight scenes. There was also a feel good romance bit added in.
Art: 8
Kyoto Animation has outdone themselves this time. They don't always do many action packed series,but this one has scenes that were very captivating to the eye. The characters were good looking. Mirai Kuriyama sure is a cutie. 


Sound: 8 


The OST was quite well done, but that wasn't what I enjoyed the most. I loved the opening an ending. They are both very catchy and I caught myself singing the songs constantly as I do my daily routine. There are also good voice actors in the series. KENN, who voiced Chase Suno and Judai Yuuki, did a good job voicing Akihito Kanbara.


Character: 9


Many of the characters are lovable and enjoyable. Mirai's ditzy, but heroic personality made her an interesting and well done heroine. Akihito's glasses fetish and Hiromi's sister complex added to the comedy of the series. Their constant jokes about little sisters and girls with glasses always made for a good laugh. 


Enjoyment: 10


I probably said it already earlier in this review, but I loved this series. It had beautiful backgrounds, interesting characters, and a plot that kept me on the edge of my seat. I'd love to see an OVA, movie, or even a second season of this if possible. It left me wanting so much more.


Overall: 10


All in all, the series was amazing. For a KyoAni series, this is my second favorite. Chuunibyou being my first, though. I recommend to give this series a try. If you like action, comedy, supernatural, and romance, this series is for you. I'm sure you'll love it just as much as I did. I'd even give this series a rewatch. Kyoukai no Kanata is great. End of story. xD

Kyoukai no Kanata (or Beyond the Boundary as I'm going to refer to it for the rest of this review) is a fairly cliche anime that got everything right. It should also be noted that this series will be getting a new season so this review might not be accurate upon that release.
Story:
Beyond the Boundary uses plenty of Red Herrings and "this is how it is, because it is" explanations to propel the plot forward. It keeps you on an IV drip of information that is just enough to grasp what is about to happen. I never feel like I knew what is going tohappen next. The universe of Beyond the Boundary has a lot of depth to it and learning more about it keeps the viewer motivated to continue watching.


Art:

Nicely drawn and animated; another series with the now standard super-detailed-almost-creepy-but-cute-at-the-same-time eyes on the female characters. The fight scenes have so much stuff going on in them and it looks fantastic. Environments were detailed and looked lived-in, it was interesting to look at the backgrounds and pick out minute details.


Sound:

Loved the music in Beyond the Boundary, especially the outro song. The FX used in the fights were also top notch.


Character:

Aside from the two main protagonists, Mirai and Akihito, none of the characters really stood out. The side characters do develop - but the issue is their personalities weren't very interesting to begin with, so I never found myself caring overmuch about them unless it related to Mirai and Akihito. Beyond the Boundary has one of the most genuine relationships between two characters that I've seen in recent memory and that relationship essentially carries the entire show from start to finish.


Enjoyment:

An acceptable story and a substantial budding romance allowed me to get fully invested into Beyond the Boundary's story, and I enjoyed it the whole way and I am very interested in the new season coming out eventually.


Overall:

A solid 8/10 anime that keeps you guessing with a intriguing plot; along with one of the most sincere love interests I've ever seen.

Kyoukai no Kanata, A spiral of emotions throughout the anime, you'll experience intense happiness, suddenly it's extreme sadness and before you know it you're back where you started and all is happy again.

I've had my eyes on this series ever since I first heard about it. The art looked gorgeous, the story sounded intriguing and I was still riding the whole "dark fantasy" wave started by Madoka Magica. I was a little discouraged after reading numerous negative reviews, but since finals ended and I had nothing else to do, I decided to sit down and watch Kyoukai no Kanata in its entirety in one sitting.
I think it's best to describe my reaction to this series in phases. Upon finishing the final episode I entered Phase 1, in which I was still feeling the adrenaline rush from theclimactic action scene and a mild sense of wonder from the ambiguous ending.


Perhaps 20 minutes later I entered Phase 2, in which I began questioning the quality of the anime I had just spent 4 hours watching. This is when I started recognizing loose ends and the almost non-existent character development.


One hour after finishing the last episode, I entered Phase 3, in which I realized that Kyoukai no Kanata is a mediocre series at best. It falls short because it tries to accomplish far too much within a mere 12 episodes.


In the opening moments, we are thrown straight into the action. Anything that even remotely resembles an explanation of the series' events is nowhere to be found in the first episode or, for that matter, any episode. The series fails to lay down a foundation for the universe in which it exists, leaving the plot an incoherent mess of shallow characters and loose ends.


The characters are as two-dimensional as they look. Little, if any, time is spent on developing the characters and instead each character is simply given a set of traits that they possess simply for the sake of possessing them; and honestly, the entire cast of characters doesn't fall very far from the tree of action anime tropes. Personally, I found Mirai to be incredibly annoying all-around and her apparent inner dichotomy between weak, clumsy, indecisive klutz and strong-willed, morally righteous warrior got on my nerves for the entire duration of the series. 


As for the rest of the main cast, although they are reasonably likable, they have no depth and no motivation for their actions other than that they are the good guys who have to fight the bad guys. Sadly, the supporting characters seem to contribute little to nothing, including the pathetic attempt at a main antagonist, who appears to aim for nothing and accomplish nothing in his maybe 30 minutes of screen time.


Kyoukai no Kanata's only redeeming factor is its presentation. The art is gorgeous, which makes the action scenes a visual pleasure, if nothing else. The series is packed with eye candy that may or may not be able to make you momentarily forget its flaws in almost every other department.


It is with great regret that I acknowledge that I did, in fact, waste 4 hours of my life on this series. Kyoukai no Kanata's only high point is episode 6, which, ironically, is essentially the equivalent of a filler episode. If you are like me and are feeling discouraged from watching this anime because of all the negative reviews--


Good. You should be.

I’m just going to get this out of the way: this may well be the most disappointed I’ve ever been in an anime. I suspect this will shift whenever I get around to watching Eureka Seven: AO, but Beyond The Boundary tops the list for now. This show actually managed to squeeze some real tears out of me, but everything surrounding this event is so flat and lifeless that it loses quite a bit of potency. Do note: I don’t really think this show is worth the time investment, so this review CONTAINS SPOILERS.
Beyond The Boundary is the story of Akihito Kanbara and Mirai Kuriyama,as well as a few others. In this show, there are youmu (spirits) and spirit world warriors. Basically, Akihito is a half-youmu (he was born to a youmu and a spirit world warrior). Kuriyama happens to be a spirit world warrior. The show opens up with her attempting to kill him. Multiple times. It's later revealed that in an injured state Akihito basically goes full youmu. That's a problem. Outside of that, the plot has little direction until the last four episodes, where it's revealed that there WAS a point and that this WAS worth the time investment. 


Frankly, the side characters are of little importance. I actually do like both of the main characters presented. Kuriyama’s character design is actually what attracted me to the show the begin with, and I was quite satisfied with it from a visual standpoint. Actually, I take back what I said earlier to note one exception: if all you care about in a show is high animation quality and fairly good comedy, then stop reading this and go watch Beyond The Boundary. Animation is top-notch; it’s actually some of the best of seen. Of course, that’s not all that makes the show pretty to look it; the art and design are great too. Kuriyama’s blood power is super cool and… oddly beautiful. I will say her power reminds me of Deadman Wonderland, but originality is tough these days. Additionally, I found her to be quite a compelling character. Her backstory is interesting, as well as somewhat tragic. As far as emotional impact goes in this show, she’s at the heart of all of it. Akihito, while also a visually well designed character, falls flat comparatively. This isn’t to say I don’t like him, but I honestly just didn’t find there was all much to him when digging into the meat of the show. 


Unfortunately, the same holds true for pretty much every other character, of which there are quite a few. I have difficulty remembering a lot of the names in the show just because there’s so little to identify anyone by. I mean, I remember the Nase family, and their role in getting Kuriyama to try to kill Akihito, but other than that I’m drawing a blank on anyone’s name. Normally, I would go on the wiki and just get their names for the sake of this review, but I feel, in this case, the fact that I don’t remember their names (and don’t care enough to try) illustrates just how bland and lifeless this show is. 


Then there’s the issues I have with the show just from a plot structure standpoint. The first few episodes were solid. They set up the world we’re looking at, set up the youmu vs. spirit warrior stuff, and set up the main characters. I will say the ideas presented in the first half of the show are inconsistent with those presented later (money is illustrated as an idea in the first half in a way it just isn’t later). Then there’s this god awful filler episode (where they fucking dance as IDOLS for fucks sake). Then the show drops any pretense of really focusing on anyone other than our two mains and just barrels to the finish. That being said, I didn’t really have a problem with this; I felt the show was finding it’s footing and focusing on the truly interesting parts of the world it was focusing on, as well as the central character relationship. We find out that the youmu in Akihito is Beyond The Boundary, which is a dangerous youmu with no physical body. Kuriyama dies to destroy Beyond The Boundary without killing Akihito, and it was honestly pretty touching. Actually, had this show ended on around episode 10, where Akihito receives a text from the dead Kuriyama, I would have given this show a fairly high score. I mean, at least that would be tragic. At least it would mean something. It’d be like a 5 Centimeters Per Second or Steins;Gate type ending; he found love and then lost it. Also, I think “I don’t feel unpleasant” was a wonderfully touching last line for Kuriyama to have. It turns this phrase that she uses for comedy and general disdain and uses it to show she’s finally happy. THIS part made me shed a tear or two. Unfortunately, the show doesn’t end there, and has two and a half episodes left. After this, it just goes off the rails. Kuriyama is still alive on an alternate dimension that also happens to be in the sky and she is part of Beyond The Boundary and… wait, what? I watched the 11th episode twice because so much damn shit happens so fucking fast. Also, I was really trying to see if the main villain has any clear motive, but nah, he’s pretty irrelevant. I questioned if he even need to be there (I’m not really clear on his role in the show. I think he doesn’t have one). Basically, what ends up happening is Akihito ends up reabsorbing Beyond The Boundary, and then because Kuriyama is part of Beyond The Boundary she dies. And yeah, that was sad. But I wouldn’t say it was any sadder than when Akihito got that text from her (if anything it was less sad because it was somewhat more intimate). Then Akihito goes on the most fake-deep ending monologue I’ve heard in a long time (it made me laugh, honestly), and then KURIYAMA IS FUCKING ALIVE. There is no explanation. Did they forget which character they made immortal? Because that was Akihito. I mean, what the fuck is this? That character died and came back to life twice in like three episodes. That’s just poor writing. 


Here, I’ll make a list of things that would have made this show good. 


-cut out the filler (episode 6)

-replace it with an episode or two fleshing out the supplementary characters 

-cut off the last two episodes

-remove the spirit warrior villain; Beyond The Boundary is enough to have as a villain 

-end the show when Akihito receives a text from Kuriyama


That would have been a great show. But that's not what we have here. This isn’t the worst show I’ve seen, but it sure did disappoint me. I give it a 4/10, maybe a 5 on a good day. I wouldn’t really say it’s worth your time.

Here we have another anime from Kyoto Animation, the company responsible for amazing works such as Chuunibyou, Clannad, Hyouka, and the Haruhi Suzumiya saga, but also created trainwrecks such as Tamako Market and K-On. When I first saw the trailer for Kyoukai no Kanata, I was really impressed by the change in genre that KyoAni was taking. Super natural was a theme lightly touched, the most being in Chuunibyou. After watching the series at first with excitement, I ended it with less satisfaction than before.
Story: 8/10
KnK started off really strong, setting up the plot and the characters excellently. It hooked you in really well, butonce the plot got going, it slowed down... a lot. They had to put a filler episode in a 13-episode series for who knows why and the story line ended up becoming bumpy because of that and other factors. The climax in the last three episodes was very much rushed thanks to the poor pacing, making it extremely hard to follow and very confusing. Still, the plot was interesting and held out a lot of potential. It was just poorly executed and could have been loads better. 


Art: 9/10 

You can never go wrong with the quality of Kyoto Animation art. KyoAni is best known for amazing art elements and fluid animation. Combine this factor with supernatural Spirit World Warrior powers, and you've got one hell of a treat for the eyes. The different character and youmu designs were colorful and no doubt was it stunning. 


Sound: 8/10

Kyoukai no Kanata's opening and ending sequences were rather average. They didn't exactly blow me away and I'd usually skip them. The background and original soundtrack music wasn't anything too amazing either. However, the voice acting was spot on. The characters were quite lively and no one seemed out of place with their voices. The too scores balance each other out, so KnK's sound was an above average 8. 


Characters: 9/10

Each of the characters here were really interesting. The main cast, consisting of the high school gang, the Nase's and Aya and Ai, all had powers and secrets among them. Seeing them interact and revealing surprising background information kept me watching the series, but the development and relationships between them was lacking. The two that got the most growth was, of course, Akihito and Mirai. To really make the characters pop, more development should have been made. Otherwise, they were interesting, likable, and mostly well rounded. 


Enjoyment: 8/10

Despite the shoddy pacing, I still really enjoyed Kyoukai no Kanata. Now, I wouldn't say that it made me super happy and excited, but it was enough for me to like watching it. I'm glad I finished it all the way through because the climax was pretty hectic in an appealing way. 


Overall: 8/10 

Every anime that Kyoto Animation releases has a tendency to be remembered as either a masterpiece or a trainwreck. Kyoukai no Kanata was able to avoid both categories and to me, was an anime to watch but not one to be remembered. It very much could have been twice as good as it was, but that fault lies in the storyline.

Labelled as a dark fantasy, Kyoukai no Kanata is an interesting show that has received quite a mixed reception, with some liking it and others criticising its strange mix of genres. In my opinion, the best way to describe what the show is like is that it is a supernatural anime with comedy and hints of slice of life.
Story: 8
Probably the weakest point of the series is the story. Kyoukai no Kanata is based in a fantasy world where Spirit World Warriors have to defeat youmu and the story follows the unique half youmu Akihito. Despite having a very interesting premise, I believe the executionwas done quite badly. The pacing of the show and action scenes were good, however, often I found that tense moments were ruined by the untimely comedy that they felt the need to put in. Also, after watching the whole show I found that its genre was not very defined, at times it felt like the supernatural action anime that it should be, and then by the next episode I felt like I was watching a slice of life. Another point I have to criticise is the fact that many points in the plot aren't explained until much later on, sometimes leaving me confused as to why what is happening is happening, and some points aren't explained AT ALL. However, despite it lacking a bit it was still interesting and enjoyable to watch.


Art: 10

Like I'd expect, the art coming from Kyoto Animation did not disappoint. The overall style of the art was great and I found that the character designs of the main characters were quite imaginative and memorable. The action scenes looked amazing, with both vibrant colours and also fluid animation, and the show had beautiful backgrounds that remained detailed both normally and during fights. Overall, there's not really anything I can criticise here.


Sound: 8

Overall I found the sound in Kyoukai no Kanata pretty awesome. I loved the opening and ending, as they both had interesting visuals but also a great song that personally I believe fit it perfectly. The voice actors were good, being able to show different emotions with conviction, and the characters had unique and memorable voices for the main cast. As for the soundtrack, to be honest I was too immersed in the show to really notice or appreciate it. Re-watching parts though, I found that the musical score was pretty good although nothing outstanding.


Character: 8

Although the fetishes may put some people off, I think that the characters are pretty good and interesting to watch. The lead characters, Mirai and Akihito, have mysterious backgrounds which are explored through the course of the series and their relationship is developed as well. However, for character development this is pretty much as far as it goes; the other characters don't really change too much and lose some character depth because of this. One thing I have to point out is that there are a lot of characters in this show who had different motives, but in the end they never really explain the reasoning behind the motives and it leaves you feeling unfulfilled. Despite that, I still found the characters overall quite intriguing and good to watch.


Enjoyment: 10

For me, the combination of amazing art, great sound and interesting plot allowed me to really enjoy the show. I gave it a 10 despite its flaws because I feel it really is worth watching and enjoying.


Overall: 9

To sum up, Kyoukai no Kanata, like all anime, has good points and bad points. However, I think that the great presentation, art and compelling plot make up for the bad points. I would recommend this to people who are open minded and like a good mix of action, fantasy and slice of life, as if you like those things you will really enjoy this show.


My personal advice if you want to properly enjoy this anime is to try not to focus too much on the slightly weak plot and just let yourself be absorbed into the show, as in the end the plot and characters are all very interesting.


Thanks for reading, and I hope this helped!

Kyoukai no Kanata started as something that I was very excited about. It had a good premise that I felt like promised a lot of stuff. However, over the course of the show I never really felt like they were able to progress the story well enough for it to be something that delivered on what it could have been. 
That said, I do not feel like I wasted my time watching Kyoukai no Kanata
Art
The animation was fantastic. This will be the show that I point to as the gorgeous staple of what high quality animation can and should be. The art style also fitvery well into the world that it existed in. Bright, happy colors existing beside the darker shades did an excellent job of matching up with what Akihito said at the end of the show, "There will always be darkness in the light, but the night is not without light too." Or something like that.\n\n
Characters\n
Regrettably, the show often fails to take itself seriously enough for the characters to reach their full potential. Most of the characters showed potential to be rich and fulfilling; they could very easily have a good show into a fantastic one, but the characters often were dragged down by jokes or by being cute. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy light hearted fluff that these characters often were just as much as the next guy, but when the potential to be something so much more than just fluff is there then I feel like I got cheated out of greatness.\n\n
Sound\n
I loved the music in this series. The closing song in particular stands out in my mind. The way many episodes would end and fade into the credits was one of the high points of the show. It does a good job of capping of each episode in a way that is satisfying and as poignant as the episode allowed itself to be.\n\n
Enjoyment\n
I enjoyed watching Kyoukai no Kanata. I started watching it after the first 11 episodes had aired so I was able to knock it all out over a weekend and then waited for the finale. I did not feel like it took any serious investment on my part and that was definitely for the best. In a show like that this one that so closely misses the mark of being fantastic I can appreciate it as a lazy, watch-it-all-in-a-weekend kind of show. I would recommend Kyoukai no Kanata to anyone who  wants to watch a goofy, fun little show with the warning that that is all that it will be: a goofy, fun little show.

As a KyoAni show, Kyoukai no Kanata or Beyond the boundary was a strange show to me. Usually they can pull together a show were slice of life and character drama works amazing, such as Clannad or its recent Sound! Euphonium. However, this is a particular case in which the drama didn't feel in the right place.
My main problem with the series was that I couldn't take it seriously. It tried to be dramatic, it tried to pull some heartstrings, but almost none of it didn't work. Why? Because it felt rushed sometimes and mostly because it was for the most part a Slice ofLife show. The best moments of the show were when the characters were having fun and weren't taking things seriously. Even the fights were packed with jokes and funny interactions between the protagonists, especially the fight with the bulb/fruit youmu, which gave us hilarious scenes of Mirai in cute outfit and the complete cast as an Idol group.


But although I had a lot of fun watching them, the second weak point of the show must be the characters. Mirai was the one who gets most of the development and the best of them all. She is great as a moe character and as heroine. Although at first she had problems due to her past, you can feel how she grows as a character all along the series. Akihito starts off good as well, but doesn't get the development needed to fully comprehend him, and although I didn't have any problems with it, his fetish may turn away some people. The same can be say from Hiromi. His powers are amazing (I particularly liked it when he made shields), but his Sister Complex can be annoying for some. This lead us to the worst character of the show: his sister Mitsuki. During the course of the series, and especially in the first episodes, she tries too hard to be the cold one who likes to be harsh and hurtful during her conversations with her friends, especially with Akihito. However, she's absolutely nothing close to Hitagi Senjouhara, and she does not even fill the shoes of the tsundere character.


Fortunately, the worst parts of the show end with her, as the animation is amazing and fluid. KyoAni is one of the best companies out there when talking about animation and art, so it wasn't surprising that Beyond the Boundary looked beautiful from beginning to end. The music and sound were good, too. However, the OST didn't stand out as much as the OP (I love Minori Chihara's voice) and the ED.


I had a lot of fun watching this show. It had an interesting story, beautiful animation and great songs, and most of the characters were fun and likeable. However, I liked it more when the show didn't want to be serious. As I've said, the best parts of the anime were when the characters interact with each other, having fun taking down pervert monsters or when Akihito and Hiromi were discussing how perfect Mirai was for them. I particularly liked the relationship between Akihito and Mirai. You could feel how comfortable they felt around each other, especially at the end of the anime, even when the final battle was taking place.


I can't wait to see the mirai-hen movie, as it will most likely give more development for our main characters.

Story: The story contains unique elements and plot twists, which really grab my attention. To gain a better knowledge of the main characters, you must watch episode 0. Afterwards the anime becomes clearer. Also, there was only one filler epsidoe, and afterwards the story continues. It is pretty fast paced, and you'll end wanting to watch more:)
Art: Animations were consistent, beautiful, and bright. You can definetly tell it's a 21st century anime.
Sound:-
Characters: All the characters have unique attributes to each of them, which I really like. At first, I didn't really like the protagonist, but as you continue you'll understand her background. 
Overall: I likedthis anime because the story keeps on going without any weird interruptions. You'll end up loving the protagonist so much that you'll laugh and cry.

I'm a fan of the anime because of it's cute art (the characters look their age, an aspect that some anime I've watched have trouble grasping), brilliant comedic relief (the repartee between the characters make me snicker), and likable characters.  
We have Kiriyama Mirai's graceful fighting skills, yet clumsy social skills, and favorite "how unpleasant" line, Akihito's glasses fetish, Mitsuki's tsundere personality, and Hiroomi's sister complex. With this colorful cast and unique story there's hardly a lull in the anime. 
In addition, the opening and ending song is the perfect measure of poignant and hopeful. 
The story had some questions that needed answering, butit didn't take away the overall enjoyment of the series.

I do not get why some people don't like this anime, how ever I respet them. 
This anime was a love story, with fighting, and most people have seen many animes like this, however this was outstanding in it's own ways. This anime did bring me down to tears because it shows you that if you don't give up on your loved ones then they will never give up on you. 
I also really liked they op/ed and the art behind it, the ending was flawless to me. As far as the character I say that they were not all over the place, youknow when in some animes they show that they go crazy, or they were always evil, I believe they stayed very real and was true to all there  main goal.  \n\n
I'm not sure if everyone is going to like this anime but if your a fan of Noragami or Chuunibyou demo Koi ga Shitai!, I think your gonna like this anime it's not the same thing but if you look at the story line, there very much alike. \n\n
Hope this was helpfully!

I have always hoped that Kyoto Animation would do a fantasy anime and here it comes! This is a proper fantasy anime with monsters, supernatural powers and fights. I enjoyed this show overall but it is not without its flaws.
Story - 7/10
The story itself is interesting but what went wrong is the pacing of the story. To be honest, I dropped the show after two episodes and only picked it up afterwards, which I am glad I did. It started off light hearted and rather slow, showing a clumsy Mirai fooling around with Akihito, the other main character. As it goes along the story isactually pretty serious and I wish they had shown it earlier to make the show more focused. The story reaches a climax, then there are some funny "filler" episodes. But then things deteriorated real fast and not long later comes the end of this 12 episodes series. I enjoyed the funny episodes, but I couldn't help thinking it may be better if they use those screen time to lay out the story fuller. Even at the end there are lots of unanswered question, which I hope they could have at least explained some of them to give a fuller sense of completeness. 


Characters - 8/10


The characters have distinctive personalities and are likeable. This show mainly focused on the two main characters, Mirai and Akihito, so there is not a lot of personality development for the side characters. But given the length of this series it can't be helped. For Sakura I find her development somewhat sudden. Nevertheless this is a nice cast. 


Sound - 8/10


The OP and ED are nice and the background music is fitting. The voice acting is good. 


Art - 9/10


Typical high standard Kyoto Animation. The battle scenes are amazing and I really like the use of the colours in this show. 


Enjoyment - 9/10


I didn't enjoy the show much at the beginning but by the end I was looking forward to the next episode eagerly. I would have given this show a 9 if not for the pacing of the story.

Spoiler free
Story: 6
Sooo much potential, people, really. My opinion in that case is personal and not 100% objective, because we aren't in front of a bad story, we are in front of a story not well told. I will not say anything about the ending, but more we approach to the final more all became...confused.
Regardless that few negative point the story remain rather enjoyable.
Art: 8
Wow. Ok, there is "moe" here and there, but the style and the animation of Kyoukai no Kanata is really good! Nice colors, nice movement and everything blend in pretty well; it's a party for the eyes!
Sound: 7
Opening and ending aren'tso memorable, like the ost, but they are more than enough to strike the target. Great work of Risa Taneda, the voice of one of the main characters.\n\n
Character: 6\n\n
They have tried. Or at least i hope they have. The character design is good (but it stand in the art rating) but about their stories...mh they are lacking. What does it mean? Well, i think they have tried to give profundity to something that doesn't deserve, or simply doesn't have, it.\n
They are stereotype, and I'm ok with it, nothing bad, they work, and it's the reason why they reach a 6, even something more, but not the 7.\n\n

It wasn't good enough for awake real, deep emotions, but it was beautiful to watch, it worth the effort. Suggested for who want to see something light that can catch the eye and don't stress the brain in any way!

Noone really knows your story until they walked in your shoes. This is the story of KnK, a story of isolation, fear, love and pain.
When reading reviews, I was suprized to find many people didn't like this show. The show focuses on a few main characters in charge of protecting the city from monsters called youmus. These charecters have a variety of different powers, from weaponry, combat skills, to more supportive roles. This is capturing and interesting, but the show doesn't stop there, It takes a closer look on a young girl with a special power, who has spent time wallowing in the stigma attachedto it. You see how she changes, improves, and learns solitude is a crutch throughout the show. 


This show isn't the best show I've ever seen, nor is it close, but it is one of the better ones out there. The charecters are really fantastic, each is unique, quirky, and has their own goals and aspirations. They may fit some common themes, but they do it well. 


The artwork is amazing, as expected from Kyoto. The charecter models are cute, and clean, making them easy to look at and caring actual humanism. The fight scenes are impeccable, some of the best i've seen in a long time. Many scenes and backdrops are also quite fantastic, and eye catching.


Story line although simple is engaging. Our 4 main characters all get appropriate screen time, you learn their stories, and see their struggles or successes. We learn about both their powers and talents, but also their normal hobbies and lifestyles. This leaves for a nice experience, as characters feel well rounded, while you also can recognize who is feeling what, and how different characters may approach different situations. 


Sound was good, but less remarkable to me compared to many of the other aspects. I just found the art and characters to be a far larger driver for my enjoyment of the show. 


Overall, KnK is a truly immersive show. You feel for the charecters, admire the art, and see a unique twist on isolation and branching out of one's niche.  I awarded this show an 8, and place it as one of my favorites. It may not be for everyone, but if you are willing to give it a shot beyond 3-4 episodes, I feel you may find a truly remarkable show hidden in the rough. Hope you have a pleasant viewing experience!

Kyoukai no Kanata in a sense sticks out like a sore thumb when it's compared to other Kyoto Animation works. It's not the fact that there's action because there was action in Chuunibyou and it still fits. To many, people love Kyo Ani for stressing points in everyday life and making them beautiful. That's more of a personal thing but there's more.
Story: The general idea of killing youmu was honestly one that I could get used to. It made sense how it connected Mirai the other characters. However, the romance between Mirai and Akihito seems forced especially if you think of Mirai's main objective whichI will not spoil. All I really wanted was a little more development. And even though this series is only 12 episodes, I've seen studios develop their characters more in this amount of time than a series with 50 episodes. And to top it all off, there was an irrelevant episode which was just an excuse to let the cute characters sing and dance.


Art: The fact that Kyoukai no Kanata is a Kyo Ani anime is enough to know that's it's gorgeous. The color palette they used is very mellow but can also pop out in action scenes because of all of the shades of red they use. But that's it. Whenever I think of this show, the first thing that comes to mind was"It was really pretty" which is good in anime, but shouldn't be your selling point.


Sound: The opening theme of Kyoukai no Kanata was honestly dramatic and mellow enough to be fitting of a show that's supernatural and slice of life. The ending is competing with the Kiznaiver ending for my favorite of all time, and the soundtrack was lovely.


Characters: The characters is what I really have a problem with. After completing this series, I can easily say that I found Akihito to be more interesting than the main protagonist, Mirai Kuriyama. Other than the fact that she was this cute megane girl who had a very cool weapon, I don't remember much about her. Akihito Kanbara and his friend, Hiroomi Nase are still kind of off. It seems that as time progresses, less and less anime have unforgettable characters. I've watched anime years ago and I still remember the personalities of side characters. Hiroomi is basically just some other supernatural guy who has a sister complex. His sister, Mitsuki, I found even more boring. 


Enjoyment: Watching the show was nice for my aesthetics, however , I found myself wanting more. So it was a somewhat bland and dare I say, "unpleasant" experience.


Overall: Kyoukai no Kanata was expected to be Kyo Ani's first dark anime but ended up falling flat on its claim and at sometimes could turn in to pure moe blob. The show isn't particularly bad, it was just disappointing despite its potential. if you're looking for a show about a cute girl fighting, then this one is for you.

*This is not a super in-depth review, just relaying my experiences with the anime*
I'm not usually that critical of anime but aspects of this show definitely pushed me to write a review about it.
Beyond the boundary has an interesting premise, leaning towards the dark side of the fantasy genre, in which powers are burdens to some who possess it. The start is pretty interesting and I did enjoy it, there was just something 'generic' in a sort of sense about it. It's not something I can really describe, it's more or less I feel I've seen it before. It doesn't really take away much fromthe enjoyment, but it makes it so it doesn't stand out far from the rest. This can be pretty much applied to the rest of the story as well, as it doesn't seem to stand out but still is interesting. And the end (without spoiling) is just really dumb with some glorious plotholes.

Story (7/10)


The art is beautiful and the character designs are also really good, the mc looks like a casual dude, yknow who looks like would be cool to hang out with, which I think is fine, but I feel isn't really up my alley because it contrasts with his personality, which is far from normal (also it may be so people can imagine them in his place, which is not what I'm looking for in an anime). They really make Mirai (the 'main' girl) look beautiful in this anime, and that coupled with the animators' ability to express emotions makes out for some really fun/cute moments. The sound design is pretty good, it accentuates the scenes and helps the emotional scenes aswell. The OP and ED are really good. Especially the really chill ending song coupled with the visuals gives a real 'feelgood' ending to the episodes, comparable to like lofi hip-hop songs.

Art (9/10) probably the best part of the anime

Sound (9/10) just really nice


The characters are probably the worst aspect of the show, though it doesn't bring the enjoyment of the show down that much. I like how both Akihito (the mc) and Mirai both learn and bond together through their isolation and create this sort of connection with one another as they can understand how each has felt. I liked Mirai, she was cute, considerate and seemed pretty interesting. She wasn't a super in-depth character, but yknow I still liked her. Now Akihito was just pretty bad tbh, towards the end he became kinda mysterious and interesting in his origins but in terms of his personality, he really didn't have one. He was kinda bland and super repetitive with his 'glasses fetish', which honestly defined his whole character, which ruined his character for me. KnK definitely exceeded my expectations, but it still did not come out on top for me. This anime is very enjoyable, containing lots of action and an interesting plot, but there were a few different routes that I wish would have been taken.
Story: 7/10
The story isn't completely original. There are "Spirit World Warriors" that fight yokai, collect the stone they receive from defeating each one, then cash them in to make a living. The Nase family, a prominent family in the anime, became wealthy through this, or so I gathered. Akihito, the main character, is best friends with two siblings from the Nasefamily. Akihito is an immortal half-human half-yokai being that the Nase family keeps a close eye on. Akihito's friends are ordered to kill him if his yokai self surfaces, but gets out of control (Apparently he can be killed if his powers are weakened. So does that really make him immortal...?)


One day, Akihito meets a girl named Mirai Kuriyama, who basically introduces herself by stabbing him in the stomach, and Akihito kindly asks her to remove it from him. She tries to kill him several times, but is obviously unsuccessful. Mirai is a member of a "cursed" clan of Spirit World Warriors that use blood manipulation to defeat yokai.


The main problem I had with the plot is how they chose to reveal everything about Mirai. For example, how did she know Akihito was immortal in the first place? We don't find this out until an episode or two before the final episode. She had been meeting with a member of the Nase family frequently because help was needed to kill Akihito, but Mirai was almost never shown speaking to her. The Nase family had tried to kill him once before when he lost control, but the person in charge of taking him down nearly died. Thus, Mirai was asked to aid in the murder of Akihito, but of course, she ends up not wanting to kill him for various reasons. In my opinion, a more gradual approach to revealing what Mirai was involved with rather than all at once would have been better.


Other than the yokai themselves, there is only one other person that is considered as a villan in the anime, and man is he unlikable. I hated him from his first appearance. You could tell that he was up to something from the very beginning, and that he was going to turn on the Nase family and cause all of the Spirit World Warriors and Akihito to be involved in quite a mess.


Art: 9/10

The animation is good for the time that the anime came out. It is aesthetically pleasing to look at with its smooth animation and its overall nice color palette. The fighting scenes were nice; the characters had a variety of movement in their attacks that wasn't completely rehashed throughout the series. I don't give it a 10/10 simply because I think there were some scenes that could have been animated better and that were a bit rushed, but overall it was some beautiful animation.


Sound: 8/10 

To be honest, I wasn't paying much attention to the sound at points, but from I can remember, it was good. Obviously, it wasn't all that memorable, but I enjoyed the opening a lot and the ending was decent.


Character: 7/10

The characters weren't completely unique. Akihito and Hiroomi, one of Akihito's friends in the anime, are the usual perverts with specific likes. Akihito loves girls in glasses, and Hiroomi has a little sister complex, which his sister Mitsuki detests. Other than that, most of the characters have fairly likeable traits. All the characters truly care about each other (aside from all of the teasing) and want to protect each other as much as possible. Mirai, too, is pretty likeable, though she may be a bit bland, but I had a soft spot for her throughout the anime for my own silly reasons.


Enjoyment:10/10

The reason I'm giving this a 10/10 is that I did not get bored. I was left confused at times, but I was engaged the whole time. It was interesting enough to hold my attention and watch it when I had the chance.


Overall: 8/10

This anime is very likeable despite a few things that I had to pick at. The action scenes and the story, although not original, kept me watching. The characters were likable and so was the animation. I enjoyed the banter the characters had back and forth at each other. It made for some good comedic relief, although it was a bit inappropriately inserted at times.


A few other minor things that I'd like to mention:

-The fact that Sakura and Mirai made up rather quickly bothered me. Mirai murdered Sakura's sister Yui, and Sakura was after Mirai for half of the anime, but they made up so quickly after one of their fights that I found it odd.

-Akihito's mom is just plain weird. Enough said.

This story's charm is how do you interpret those unexplained mysteries. 'Star Wars a New Hope'is a great example, a window opens and you get to peek at a Universe, the expectador falls in the middle of a story and as you grasp some of it, by the end they don't "explain" it to you, but it doesn't matter because the story was told and the unexplained was exactly the charm of it. Story 5/10
Other than the art and I guess the sound, this was the most pleasant part of the show, which isn't really a complement. Sound/Music 6/10

Kyoto Animation is a Production Studio that recently has been very well known for its cute animation style and very moe influenced shows. They are hated by some people for founding the moe-blob genre and basically being the sole company to make it as popular as it is. But, they are also loved for exactly the same reason, as there are many people (such as myself), that simply fell in love with shows such as K-On and Lucky Star. There are several reasons to why Kyoto Animation rose to popularity, most of them being discussed badly, but there is one undeniable thing about the AnimationStudio itself and that is its unbelievably high production standards! Although there are almost no recent Anime by Kyoto Animation, that included fights or anything similar, the Animation always was incredibly fluent and amazingly detailed! Now imagine... An Anime with these production standards, based around a fantasy fighting premise, with just as much moe as we are used to from KyoAni! Ladies and gentlemen, today's topic is the anime that combines all of that, Kyoukai no Kanata!


Story:

The story of Kyoukai no Kanata is set in a world similar to ours, except that there exist beings called Youmu, which basically are demons that can have any shape or form, ranging from humans, over cats to something along the line of a fruit... There also are those who make their living off fighting exactly these Youmu, by killing them and selling the stones they got out of it. They are called Spirit Warriors and for the most part have some kind of ability as well. The plot itself is about Akihito Kanbara an ordinary high school boy that goes to school like every other person... except for one little twist: he is a half youmu... One day, he stumbles upon a girl that seems to be wanting to jump from the roof of the school he goes to. As fast as he can, he runs up the stairs to confront the girl and after telling her in an epic speech, just how much he loves glasses, she proceeds to stab him, only to find out that he is immortal. The girl, Mirai is a Spirit Warrior and her goal from now on is to kill the immortal Half-Youmu that is Akihito and basically uses him as a punching bag to get better at hunting.


Now, I guess you can imagine that this is not all the story has to tell, but that there is a lot more behind it than this! However, I am not going to give away anymore than this, as I am a little afraid to spoil anything for you! The story for Kyoukai no Kanata is weird to review... It honestly is nothing too impressive. It starts out strong with an interesting premise that certainly has a lot of potential, but soon takes a little bit of a nosedive! The show forgets to focus on the plot itself, but rather goes in the direction of doing some slice of life stuff that we are so used to seeing from KyoAni. Those episodes for the most part were good for developing the characters and their interactions, but sometimes not necessary. Now don't get me wrong, I didn't enjoy it less, I just think some things absolutely wouldn't have been necessary and they should have rather made those to be an OVA. Anyway, back to topic. The story picks near the end of the show up again and even proceeds to get some feels out of the viewer. The ending of the show is worth noting as well, as it was one of the most satisfying endings that I have seen in a while and while it left a bitter aftertaste for what the characters had to go through, it ends the show in a perfect way and left me, personally, very satisfied! However the show has one more fatal flaw and that is the setting itself. The world on its own is really interesting, but, unfortunately, its potential is not fully used! I might be nitpicking at this point, but I feel like Kyoukai no Kanata is a show that didn't use all of what it could have. It has a lot more potential than what it used, as it didn't explain all of what happened in the world. What exactly are Youkai? Why do the Spirit warriors exist? None of these questions get addressed and I do hope that KyoAni at some point in time decides to actually clear up all those questions and make a second season for exactly that sake! I would be happy about it at least...


Now for the most part, the show's story really isn't the strongest and it really is not what makes this anime as enjoyable as it is, but it is it's storytelling. The way the story is told, never fails at keeping the viewer interested and always makes him come back for the next episode, even though nothing too interesting happened! It is that, what makes the anime really enjoyable and way better than it should have been! It makes the show a lot more fun to watch and with an ending such as the one Kyoukai no Kanata presented, it certainly concludes as a rather average plot line, that has excellent execution.

7.4/10


Characters:

For the characters of Kyoukai no Kanata, it basically is the same as for the story. Most characters are only a variation of stereotypes and none of them are really original! Our main protagonist Kanbara Akihito at first is one of the blandest main characters that I have seen so far. He starts off as your generic Light Novel main characters, as he seems to only exist for the purpose of helping people. He doesn't really have any further motives other than "I want to help you" at first. However, it is not until a short time into the show that this changes. We get to know more about him and we can get attached to him. He even does develop a little bit and even though the development, by far is not the best one and not the biggest one that I have seen so far, I can safely say that it was enough to keep me interested in him and I didn't see any need to develop him more than he was. Some people might only see him as the glasses-loving douche bag, but honestly, I thought he was a lot more than that!


The second main character is Kuriyama Mirai. She is the character that fits the best in KyoAni's concepts, as she is the moe induced, glasses wearing moe, clumsy moe stereotype and fills that role surprisingly well. Just as for Akihito, she is rather generic to begin with and at first doesn't really have too much of a character but more of a stereotype attached to her. But we get to know her over the course of several episodes dedicated to her and her relationship with others. She starts to develop as well and becomes just as Akihito a memorable character that can stand on it's own, without being a mere moe stereotype.


The side characters for Kyoukai no Kanata all are rather interesting, the most notable being the two siblings Hiromi and Mitsuki, which both do get a fair bit of focus but not nearly as much development. The two of them are  a lot of fun to watch whenever they are on screen, with Hiromi having a little sister fetish and not being hesitant about showing that. The other side characters all get a little focus, but nothing too important and while they all have their stereotypical roles, again, that is totally fine, as they all are fun to watch!


Kyoukai no Kanata in total does not have a single ground-breaking characters. None of them are too innovative, but all are stereotypes that have been used pretty often before. However, the show is completely fine that way! In the same way as the storytelling is executed in such a good way, that the story suddenly got a lot better, the characters get a lot better through how well everything around them is written. What KyoAni is by far best at is writing character interactions. One can argue against K-On or Haruhi however much he wants, it is undeniable, that the interactions of the characters are either hilarious or at least well written. Even in Kyoukai no Kanata, KyoAni doesn't fail at that point, but makes the characters really likeable by letting them interact with each other. I think that without his Mirai, Akihito might have been the bluntest character of all time and that without Akihito Mitsuki would have been the most generic tsundere ever. A character cannot shine if it doesn't interact and that is what KyoAni is able to pull off again and again. They understand how to recycle a stereotype that they have been using for ages and make it feel fresh over and over again. People can see that it in K-On, Kyoukai no Kanata and heck, even Free! to some extent uses the same stereotypes only in a male field. The characters don't need to be completely original as long as they feel that way. That is the secret of the character cast behind Kyoukai no Kanata.

8.4/10


Animation:

As I already mentioned several times, Kyoukai no Kanata has been done by Kyoto Animation, a production studio that is well known for it's extremely high production standards and as it was to be expected, Kyoukai no Kanata looks damn amazing! The fight scenes are some of the most fluent I have ever seen and even while only in Slice of Life mode, the show looks beautiful. The backgrounds are stunning and the animation is detailed to an extent that lets your jaw drop several times. It is one of the best looking shows I have seen so far and is almost at the point where it would be good enough to receive a 10/10. The only problem I have with it, is that it sometimes while fast paced scenes, relies on still frames. There are a few stylistic still screens, that I can forgive, but sometimes, during fights, I cannot just ignore them.

9.7/10


Sound:

The OST for Kyoukai no Kanata has been scored by Hikaru Nanase, who was also responsible for shows like Scrapped Princess and Phantom: Requiem for the Phantom. The Soundtrack is a mix of happy slice of life tracks and darker drama tracks. While the SoL tracks are rather generic and would fit into almost every happy-go-lucky slice of life show, the drama bits certainly do suit the show really well! They are well composed and part of an OST that in total really compliments the show it is attached to. It might not be as good as let's say Attack on Titan's OST, but it certainly stands its ground against many other shows. 


The opening for the show sounds rather good being sung by the same artist who did the Gargantia opening and I did like it, but the ending song definitely was a lot better! I am a huge fan of KyoAni endings, ever since I saw Chuunibyou, as they often have a surreal feeling to it, that often even fits the show. For Kyoukai no Kanata that feeling returns and it doesn't disappoint. Coupled with the gorgeous animation from KyoAni, both the opening and ending were brilliant.

8.1/10


Kyoukai no Kanata has been a fairly enjoyable from the beginning of the show on. It had its downfalls but always has been rather interesting for me. With the cool premise, the amazing animation and the for the most part really likeable character cast, I think that it really did a good job of delivering an enjoyable anime. It might not be perfect and it might not even be amazing at most things, but the way it presents itself is its biggest strength. The plot, really, is not too good, the characters are all stereotypical, but it has a charm that not every anime has and that is what I love about it, but that could just as well be me simply fanboying over my, by far, favorite Animation Studio of all time!


Now, as I calculated all the scores for Kyoukai no Kanata (being story, characters, animation, sound and my personal enjoyment), I got to an average score of 8.4/10. It is a show that might have its flaws, but certainly does a good job of getting across what it wants to get across. It might not have the best story but succeeds in presenting it. The show, at this point in time, has been licensed by Sentai Filmworks.

The arc I've seen, which pretty much seems to have settled in these 4 episodes, did develop a relationship between the main character and  girl with glasses which with actual dialogue, could've been interesting because from a story telling perspective, as far as things were laid out, the show knows how to do it. It does. It builds up the backstory of main girl, drew parallels between the main character and her, explained why they would help each other and so on. Of course there are some terrible leaps of logic at the beginning (You're immortal, a girl tries killing you as in she stabs you, you're probably in pain. Who the fuck would talk casually to anyone that does that? Let alone want to help her wholeheartedly with anything?) but the way the relationship developed made sense if you ignore my paranthesis. 


Basically the comedy of the show ruins the story but I can see some basics in the way of telling the story are set up in what I've seen and they seem solid. Too bad they're wasted on logic gaps because the world wasn't explained or perhaps poorly thought out and terrible fetishistic comedy that take away from the story. I mean, I suppose that sort of comedy has its audience but you're trying to tell a serious story, at least it looks like you do. And it's not like you can't have comedy and also a serious story, that's not what I'm saying. What I'm saying is that the story tries to settle a relationship between two characters, of which one understand what the other endures and tries helping them through it and it does this well. All that then is undermined in the next scene where the main character will say "I wanna fuck glasses yay bifocals woooooooooo" because realistically, nobody will just all of a sudden be like "I see this person struggling and I wanna help them because I relate to them." to "Who needs gloryholes when you can fuck someone through glasses with a missing lense?" without even mentioning your concern for this person to your apparently one and only friend. There are other shows who mostly deal in shenanigans for a while but when things get serious, the story does not underwhelm the seriousness of those things. It does not scoff at them.


Also the story does have some cliches, but compared to other things, they hardly matter.


The one other thing I didn't talk about is the sound which I didn't really notice, since the series has the fantasy genre and I played quite a bunch of video games fitting that area, I'll just pin it on that and say the reason I didn't notice the OST is due to that and call it average. 


Anyway for the story, I can't really recommend the show to you. But if the fetishistic humor sounds like a plus to you, maybe that will help you with seeing the story in a different way than me. The show isn't ecchi, so don't expect that, expect it only as something meant to be humorous, not sexual. Other than that, I got nothing. The fighting scenes while animated well, that's the only praise I can give them, really. There's no sense of urgency because you already know how they're gonna go or is there anything particularly fresh or exciting about them other than the animation choices. The story I already talked about and yeah. You do you. Ultimately the show's humor didn't phase me and took away from the story that already had some logic gaps.

"How unpleasant" wouldn't be the over-used tag line I would use for this anime, rather I would use the opposite.
Kyokai no Kanta ("beyond the boundary/horizon") is a fantasy/supernatural central themed with some aspects of slice of life. It turns from quirky, light heart episodes to a plot intensified second half. It is definitely worth your attention and even more so to watch the first few episodes to get a gist of it.
NOTE: This review can be perceived as subjective for certain aspects of the review, but I will try to make it as objective as possible. 
[Story (7/10)]
The plot of KyoAni is very promising andhas a lot of potential - a world inhabited by 'youmu' and spirit world warriors. Although it being interesting and holding potential it is unfortunate to say it was executed poorly, given the side "fillers" where it reverted back to its slice of life and comedic scenes, it took away the much needed time to properly depict the many questions that arise with the series.


However the series does give you a kick in the face as the plot thickens the further you go into the anime where everything starts connecting together and makes you think "that makes so much more sense now."


[Art (10/10)]

>Animation: (5/5)

Something which is usually hard to notice is how smooth and fluid the animation in KyoAni is. The fight scenes are very good and once again, consistent which should be a buying factor for any good animations. Even the character interactions contain small things like body language instead of the typical eyes widening. Definitely one of the stronger points, and this point is further reinforced by its outstanding art style.


>Art: (5/5)

The scenery, the characters, the colours and the consistency - KyoAni absolutely blasts away everything and inspires me as a hobbyist digital artist with its superior style of art and the consistency of detail put into all scenes of the anime. It's extremely pretty at almost all points of the anime - given the fact it IS an animation where having 'outstanding' art constantly is something not you see in everyday animation.


[Sound (8/10)]

>Music (4/5)

The music is very fitting to each scenes, although it doesn't make you fall in love and force you to find it and download it - it certainly does its job of setting the mood. Properly matching the composition of instruments to each scene - soft for more emotional, upbeat for action and etc. I also enjoy it when they soft fade the closing of the episode with the opening of the 


The opening wasn't too much of a pulling factor for me, it was enjoyable without blatantly spoiling anything major in the plot (something I see a lot of anime's do..)

The ending I found to be one of the most beautiful endings I've seen in a while. This is very subjective but I enjoyed the style it portrayed with the deeper meaning towards certain symbols showed. They really held their head high and showed off what they can do and compose beautiful art, beautiful animation with the support of awesome music. It's worth noting that I'd watch the ending through: something I never do unless it's worth listening/watching.


>Voice Acting (4/5)

I feel like the voice acting has been done very well in the sense that the voices are distinctive in their own rights. They portrayed emotions well enough, when asserting rage or expressing sadness - props to the voice actor/actresses.


[Character (7/10)]

Character's in the series were something that I found to be better than what I've expected. The development albeit minimal due to aforementioned 'slice of life filler episodes', was sub-par at best but managed to get out what they could. But an extreme positive was the character dynamics and interactions. Each character show uniqueness and distinctiveness which branches out from the 'generic' group, where they all have strange, very strange (glasses...) personalities, but still manage to get warm interactions with one another - an enjoyable experience.


[Enjoyment (8/10)]

This is by no means your average of an anime, it has amusing scenes, beautiful scenes, sad scenes and cool fighting scenes. I thoroughly enjoyed the series and if given the chance to watch the sequel I would gladly with no complaints as it holds much potential to the core.

Kyoto Animation was well known for their anime "K-On", "Hyouka" & "Free". This time, Kyoto Animation made the anime "Kyoukai no Kanata" or "Beyond the Boundary". Though I really thought that there might be room of improvement for this anime.
STORY (6):
The story follows Akihito who rescues Mirai, a Spirit World Warrior, from jumping off the building. And things start to happen. I couldn't explain the details.
Basically, the Spirit World Warriors are humans who are trained to defeat Youmu. Youmu are creatures that attack human. I wouldn't know how they evolve.
The best part was when in episode 6, the youmu explodes in yellow liquidafter their performance.


Actually, the story never explained about the purpose of youmus and especially how "Beyond the Boundary" takes place. The anime just leaves me with more questions unanswered.


ART (7):


As you can tell, the art design is cute just like some people say when "Kyoto Animation" creates moe anime. In fact, I like the character designs and the supernatural scenes. They are good. In fact, this anime made use of glasses like Mirai, she wears red glasses and Akihito was astounded by that.



SOUND (7):


I like the Opening and ending song. The opening is the title of the anime itself by Minori Chihara. The ending is "Daisy" by Stereo Drive Foundation. Daisy is like the flower.


CHARACTER (5):


The characters are the weakest part of the show. They never explain what their purpose in life is. We only get to understand Akihito and Mirai better because they are the main characters.

Mirai is clumsy but she has determination to fight youmu and protect the world.


The Nase family are the most interesting part of the show though sadly they didn't get enough showtime unlike compared to Akihito & Mirai.


In fact, I really loved to see what is their purpose in defeating youmu. 


I really wished that this anime would try to develop the characters especially Yayoi who is Akihito's mom.


Miroku Fujima, the main villain, was not memorable because I have no back story about what happened to Miroku and Izumi in the past about why Miroku became the villain that he is now.


CONCLUSION (6):


Based on my rating, I really couldn't know whether I should hate or like this anime because I really felt that the story could have been better if they just explain about youmu and the characters' objectives.


It is not that I dislike this show, I feel that it could have been handled better if the characters were given enough time to realize their actions and purpose. Nevertheless, this anime is okay though I wished it could have been better. I also heard that the OVA can address the questions that wasn't answered. I also hope so for the upcoming OVA.


But if you are a KyoAni fan, you probably might find something you might like in this anime.


So I will give it a 6 out of 10.

An awesome anime from KyoAni. Kyoukai no Kanata has everything you can expect from a romance, comedy, action, supernatural anime and it fulfills everything to the maximum. I've seen this series 3 times and still watch it when I have the time. It's animation is superb so you never get bored of it, it's got a good opening and ending song as well as an insert song. It's got awesome characters and nice action scenes.
Story 9/10:
Exterminators have the duty of ridding this world of demons. Though it may seem kinda dark from this but it's not. The demons are just your everyday pest and arenot around to take over the world. But a very strong demon is present in Kanbara Akihito and Kuriyama Mirai is called to exterminate him. It's just that he is immortal. So, there daily life is filled with comedy, romance, and some fights. And let's add some unique friends and family to the situation and you've got an amazing anime. Though, not much is told about the past and future about the demons and exterminators but I don't think this is that type of anime. It's just for enjoyment and it does it's job perfectly.


Art 10/10:

KyoAni everybody. What else do you expect except state of the art character designs, backgrounds and animation.


Sound 9/10:

Nice opening and a lovely ending. As well as an insert song "Future Star" that shows in one episode.


Character 9/10:

The main protagonist, Kanbara Akihito, has a fetish for girls with glasses.

His friend, Hiroomi Nase, is a siscon. They both have their own funny routine as well.

Kuriyama Mirai, a bespectacled beauty, a strong exterminator and a romance interest.

Mitsuki Nase, the sister of Hiroomi and the only one with a cool head. 

Each character has their own special power which makes it interesting to watch.


Some other characters like Izumi Nase make the series a thousand times better. And some bad guys too which look pretty damn cool if you ask me. The past of Mirai and Akihito is briefly shown but more focus is given to Mirai. 

Since it's 12 episodes, most of the characters just appear and don't have much of a background but don't worry, they all have their own unique personality that makes the anime really amazing and gives a new surprise in each episode. New characters are introduced and some past friends are also visited to make the experience more deep.


Enjoyment 10/10:

From the start to the end, there is not one moment where I got bored. Each episode is filled with comedy that makes you laugh and action scenes that get you pumped up. Superpowers in this anime are really nice and fights range from one on one combats with demons and other exterminators to large scale battles with multiple allies and enemies. Some episodes are also dedicated for the development of the relation between the characters and after all the action and heartbreak, a happy ending is just what everyone needs giving this anime a perfect ending.


Overall, this is an anime I would recommend to anyone. I don't care what genre you prefer, this anime is awesome for anyone. I've recommended it to many friends and have gotten amazing feedback. DO NOT MISS OUT ON THIS ANIME.

STORY:
The story of Beyond the Boundary is really touching and lovable. I thought it was unique for a romance anime, and especially enjoyed the amazing action that isn't usually associated with anime under the genres of romance, comedy and slice of life. The storyline was wonderful however I thought the climax and its explanation was a little rushed and had a few plot holes, not to mention I believe the ending was quite far fetched and didn't make much sense but I was still happy with how the story ended. The explanations of what was going on was a little brief and I found myselfre watching some parts to get whats going on; despite that, I really loved the concept of the story. 


ART:

The art in this anime was very beautiful and typical of Kyoto Animation. I loved the attention to detail and thought the fight scenes were very well animated which I didn't expect at all. I found myself shocked at how stunning alot of the scenes were during battles.


SOUND:

The sound is fairly good, I really liked both the opening and ending and thought they were both very well composed. The background music was good but not exactly memorable.


CHARACTERS:

Considering its such a short anime with a fairly complex story line, they did a good job of giving characters depth. Unfortunately I didn't get a lot of background from some of the characters I wanted to know more about, for example Mirai Kuriyama and Akihito Kanbara, but I would blame this fault on the short run the series was given.


ENJOYMENT:

There wasn't a moment of BtB I didn't enjoy, I was constantly laughing at the antics of the four main characters or feeling the sheer emotion towards the end of the anime. I really enjoyed the series and never found a dull moment. 


OVERALL:

Overall I believe BtB is an amazing anime, prior to watching the anime I had heard quite alot of fuss over this series and was ready to be slightly disappointed by the anime but I really wasn't, it lives up to all the praise I've heard from many fans. The anime has a nice balance of multiple genres making it different from your average romance, comedy, slice of life. I'll definitely be re watching this in the future and will recommend it to any fantasy lover!

Kyoukai no Kanata, while amazing in artwork and having a promising story, does have its faults, which I will reveal first.
While I said the story is promising, the way the anime actually went about it was poor. Humor is widely used to break the tension, and while it normally would succeed, Beyond the Boundary happened to force in the comedy where it just wouldn't fit. At times, it does fit perfectly, but then they decide, "Hey, we already started, why don't we push it even further?!" and break the purpose of comedic relief. Now, the actual story did benefit from the bit of humor, butthe jokes oftentimes became overused. 


Continuing on, the actual concept behind the anime is pretty amazing. When applied, however, everything was smashed together in a smorgasbord of choppily rushed episodes. I imagine that if they were to remake it all utilizing two seasons, they would have been able to use the full extent of such a grand concept. The last four episodes were just the epitome of "We're out of time, hurry up!" Not only do they oftentimes leave you confused by what's happening, sometimes they start you off confused as well. And it isn't a "deeper meaning" confusion; no, this confusion is simply due to the lack of details and events, all while mixing this together in a disorganized mess.


Next, the art: The cuts in-between scenes are very rigid, making it feel like just an automatic Powerpoint presentation transitioning through the slides after the content finished playing. Apart from this terrible way of transitioning, the artwork itself is quite beautiful. The characters, although not overly unique in their design, do have quite a bit of detail placed into them. The environment is well drawn, and the animation is pretty good. At times it does lose its smoothness, but it tends to stay pretty consistent at 720p and even 480p.


Now, the characters and their personalities are a different story. There are few epiphanies, and even fewer developments. The only characters who seem to truly grow, rather than simply gain the ability to call each other friends, are Akihito and Kuriyama. Even then, it's just watching two selfishly depressed teenagers going through their lives together. The characters also act very predictably, and it is easily noticed who has secrets, who actual is an antagonist, and who actually knows what's going on.


Although the only truly redeeming feature of this anime is the art, I did greatly enjoy this. So much, in fact, that I personally rank it as an 8, despite the overall objective 6 here. If you're looking for something really nice to watch, then by all means, go ahead. I would definitely rewatch this myself. Simply knowing that it has great potential from the start is just fantastic food for thought, allowing the mind to run rampant with what could have been if this anime weren't so rushed. However, if potential is not your forte, and you'd prefer not having to think about what could have been, then, unless art can win you over, I would avoid this.
